Posts.Content: Hi Tre   Thanks for your concern.  I appreciate it.  The hospital that did my biopsy usually doesn't have to send the specimens out. I work for the same hospital.  The concern is that 2 path dr's didn't agree on the matter.  IE, if we look at a cloud and I say it looks like a flower but you say it looks like a person the results would be different.  My family does have a high cancer rate on my fathers side. My father died of lung cancer with mets to the brain.  My grandfather died of bladder cancer, my Aunt had breast cancer (she got a masectomy), my cousin who is in his 40's has bladder cancer, so now you can see why I am so not optomistic.  I would just think to get a mastectomy if it comes back positive.  Just get it out.    I will keep you posted as far as my results go.  Thanks again for your concern.      Bonnie :)   On 2/13/2009 trehouse60 wrote: Hi Bonnie, Hard to answer your questions, not knowing more about your situation.   If you had the biopsy done at a very small medical center, they may actually send a lot of biopsy samples to another facility for evaluation.  If you had it done at a larger center that deals with cancer a lot, then I would say probably not so often that they send samples out. However, it is good that they are checking with someone else if they have the least concern as to what this is.  Better to have to wait a little longer for test results that are reliable, than to be given a hasty result that might not be accurate. As to lumpectomy or mastectomy, that will depend a lot on your biopsy result.  If this is a slow growing, high grade cancer, depending upon where it its in your breast, how big it is, and at an early stage, most likely lumpectomy is sufficient.  If it's a faster growing and/or more invasive cancer, or a low grade cancer, they may want you to have a mastectomy regardless. (I know many people are confused about the difference between grade of cancer and stage of cancer - most people think they are the same thing, but they're not.  Grade of cancer means how highly differentiated the cells are - the more differentiated, the easier the cancer is to treat, and the higher it will be graded.  So a grade 4 cancer is much better to have than a grade 0 cancer.  Differentiated means how well-formed the cells are and how specific the cells are in development.   Stage of cancer indicates how advanced it is - whether it is  just in one spot, or has begun to move/spread to other parts of the body.  The lower the stage number, the better the situation - you want to hear stage 1, 1a, or 1b, as opposed to stage 2 or higher.) I personally lean toward breast conservation for women.  I think taking more tissue than you have to begs for trouble in terms of recovery and function thereafter, not to mention self - image. But I also think (to borrow the comments of several other posters to the board!):  it's just boobs.  You can replace the girls, but you can't replace your life.  For women who have a very fast growing, agressive cancer - perhaps best to try to clean it all out with a mastectomy right then and there, rather than waiting to see if they got clear margins around tissue removed with a lumpectomy.  There also is the matter of genetics - women who are diagnosed with oncogene for breast cancer might do well to have the entire breast removed.  (I am assuming that is NOT you, or you would have mentioned it??) Please let us know when you get your results back.  If it's really good news, we will all be glad to do the happy dance with you.  If it's not so good news, there are plenty of really good people who participate on the site and can give you great support as you move on through treatment. Sincerely, Tre

Posts.Content: going crazy is exactly what I am doing.  I am a 44 year old who has been put through the ringer and still don't have an answer, I know it can't be good.  On dec 20th of 07, I had a screening mammogram and it came back with calcs. so then I was told that I needed a diagnostic mamm, that came back inconclusive as well.  I had to have a sterotactic bx and when they did that, they saw 2 areas of concern, and that came back atypical ductual hyperplasia so  the pathologist recommended an exciosional biopsy. They reviewed my slides and were still uncertain, so they sent them to Johns Hopkins for a second opinion.  Johns Hopkins asked my pathologist for my tissue block because they weren't sure by just reviewing the slides. On top of that, this past friday, Feb 20, I wound up having a breast seroma that errupted through my breast and it looked and felt like I was hemmorraging and was rushed to the Er.  I am now on Antiobiotics and the hole in my aerola is draining and the dr wont stitch it because he said that would cause an infection because my breast needs to drain.  He said it will heal on its own.  I am going stir crazy.  I am so strong in front of my friends and family but now here I am, right now, it is 4:30 in the morning, I can't sleep I am scared as hell not knowing what the hell my result is going to be.  They keep telling me to stay positive,but how can I?  I know it isn't going to come back benign, because if it was benign, why would they have gone through all of this? Begnin is benign cut and dry.   I appreciate my pathologist sending my specimens to Johns Hopkins, they are a great hospital, so whatever dx they come back with, I will be satisfied .I know what I am going to do if it comes back maliginant, I am doing a simple mastectomy with the tram flap procedure, but the waiting is killing me. My surgeron says he wont do a lumpectomy because my breasts are small to begin with and the amt he would have to take out would make my breast to small, so the simple mastecomy would be the way to go.  I can't thank my drs enough for the lengths they are going through for me.  Any opinions?
